column4: After update udev at my initrd is broken - it does not even create /dev/sda* disks, /dev is almost empty.
thats not done on initrd
ah, you're right, that's formally called initramfs.
anyway, that does not create any difference - my /dev is empty and initramfs script can't find root device (/proc/devices has proper devices, so kernel is ok)
your problem is with other partitions or is with your system partitions like / /usr /home /boot ...
I'm quite confident that the issue is udev-related as I can mount everything by hands (see https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/cryptsetup/+bug/450620/comments/18 for details)
looking at you bug post I only can assume that the problem is on your lvm partition
this isn't exaclty a bug. Do you know what you're doing when using LVM fs?
yes. I set it up using usual text install, evreything was ok, then I installed all suggested updates - and voila, I have to rescue system from bare bash shell :-)
Hmm did you updated the kernel too?
yes, according to /var/log/apt/term.log my kernel was upgraded from 2.6.31.14.27 to 2.6.31.20.33
if your lvm partition was working fine, and it says okay there, them the problem is with your NTFS drive
do you have any idea why initramfs may be interested in NTFS partition? :-)
did you read my last 3 comments? My irc just droped here

the last comment I see was about NTFS - I'm sure, it's not the reason. As you can see, I find out that udevadm script was broken (see comment #20), now I've just understood WHY it is broken and have some idea how to repair it :-)
I've resolved the issue - https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/cryptsetup/+bug/450620/comments/21
was about your ntfs kernel drive?
not at all :-)
it was half-upgraded udev
good solution
I just don't get it why did you had to created those nods  by hand
broken udev could not create them ;)
no, udev was broken as dpkg was interrupted for some reason (don't know why, I have some assumption though) I had to run dpkg --configure -a
